title: R44430
content: The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) administers programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) to improve criminal justice responses to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for OVW was $489 million, with proposed increases for various grants and initiatives. The Obama Administration proposed funding increases for various programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA), including orders, civil legal assistance, grants for combating violence on college campuses, grants for combating abuse against the elderly, and grants for strengthening tribal justice systems' response to domestic violence on tribal lands. Additionally, new initiatives were proposed to reduce firearm lethality in domestic violence cases and enhance responses to campus sexual assault. Funding for the STOP Formula Grant program was proposed to be reduced by $15 million. Congress adopted a $326 million transfer from the Crime Victims Fund for OVW, but largely declined to support other proposals. Funding was increased for grants to encourage arrests in domestic violence cases and enforce protection orders, as well as grants to strengthen tribal justice systems' response to domestic violence on tribal lands. The Obama Administration proposed funding increases for various programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA), including grants for combating violence on college campuses and strengthening tribal justice systems' response to domestic violence on tribal lands. Congress largely declined to support the Obama Administration's proposals, except for a $326 million transfer from the Crime Victims Fund for OVW. Funding for grants to encourage arrests in domestic violence cases and enforce protection orders was increased, but not at the level proposed. Congress also maintained funding for STOP grants at the FY2016 level. The Office of Justice Programs manages various grant programs, including the National Institute of Justice and Bureau of Justice Statistics. The Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account funds operations for these programs. The Obama Administration requested a $154 million budget for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017, a 32.8% increase from the previous year. This account funds the Bureau of Justice Statistics, National Institute of Justice, and other programs. Congress provided $89 million for FY2017, a 23.3% decrease largely due to the lack of support for new initiatives proposed by the Administration. The Obama Administration proposed funding for research on domestic radicalization under the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account. Congress provided $89 million for this account for FY2017, a decrease of 23.3% from the previous year. Funding for the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account, which includes various grant programs, was also reduced. The Administration's FY2017 request for this account was $1.098 billion, 22.1% less than the previous year. The Obama Administration proposed significant cuts to various grant programs under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account for FY2017, including the elimination of funding for programs such as SCAAP, Paul Coverdell Forensic Sciences Improvement Program, grants for trafficking victims, John R. Justice program, and tribal assistance program. However, funding for grants to assist trafficking victims from the Crime Victims Fund was proposed. Additionally, a 7% allocation was suggested for tribal justice programs, and a reduction in funding for the JAG program was proposed. The Obama Administration proposed cuts to various grant programs under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account for FY2017, including reducing funding for the JAG program, National Criminal History Improvement program, and DNA backlog reduction initiatives. However, funding was increased for reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for residential substance abuse treatment, and programs to assist people with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Additionally, new programs were requested, such as funding for the Byrne Incentive Grant program. The Obama Administration proposed cuts to various grant programs under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account for FY2017. However, funding was increased for reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for residential substance abuse treatment, and programs to assist people with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Additionally, new programs were requested, such as funding for the Byrne Incentive Grant program and other initiatives to improve the juvenile and criminal justice systems. Congress reduced funding for the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account by 9.1%, or $128 million, for FY2017. Some of the reduction is due to Congress choosing to fund several programs as set-asides from the JAG program instead of funding them as individual line items under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account. Available funding for the JAG program decreased from $347 million for FY2016 to $335 million for FY2017. Congress reduced funding for the JAG program by $73 million for FY2017, resulting in a decrease in available funding from $347 million to $335 million. The Consolidated Appropriations Act eliminated $30 million in funding for tribal assistance programs but authorized DOJ to use up to 7% of funding from various accounts for tribal justice assistance programs. Additionally, $103 million was provided for an opioid initiative, with funding coming from various existing programs. Enforcement Assistance account for an opioid initiative, funded through various existing programs like Drug Courts, Veterans Treatment Courts, and Prescription Drug Monitoring. Congress allocated $13 million for programs authorized by the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act of 2016. No new programs proposed by the Obama Administration were funded. The Juvenile Justice Programs account includes funding for grant programs to reduce juvenile delinquency and improve juvenile justice systems. The Obama Administration requested $334 million for FY2017. The Obama Administration requested $334 million for the Juvenile Justice Programs account in FY2017, proposing increases for various grant programs and initiatives to improve outcomes for system-involved youth. Funding for the Juvenile Accountability Block Grants was also requested to be restored. The Obama Administration requested funding be restored to the Juvenile Accountability Block Grants ($30 million) and proposed a Smart on Juvenile Justice Initiative for better outcomes for system-involved youth. Congress appropriated $247 million for Juvenile Justice Programs in FY2017, reducing funding for some programs and declining to fund new programs proposed by the Administration. In FY2017, Congress allocated funding for mentoring grants, Title V grants, and the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative. The Obama Administration's request for the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) Office was $74 million more than the previous year, with a proposed increase in funding for the hiring program. Congress appropriated $222 million for the COPS account. In FY2017, Congress allocated $42 million more for the COPS hiring program, with a total appropriation of $222 million. Funding for the hiring program remained unchanged at $137 million after set-asides. Congress also increased funding for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program by $3 million. Additionally, $8 million was set aside from the COPS hiring program for the POLICE Act of 2016, allowing grants to be used for active shooter training. The Administration requested $500 million for the 21st Century Justice Initiative in its FY2017 budget for DOJ. The initiative aimed to invest $5 billion over 10 years in criminal justice reform efforts, focusing on reducing crime, reversing practices leading to unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust. States could use the funding to change laws and policies, promote critical initiatives, and address issues in adult and juvenile systems.
